title: The loss of DFG
body:
Is not the death of the mage class in League of Legends. The nerfs to mana regen are not the death of the mage class. Making the Morellonomicon cost more is not the death of the mage class. Then focusing their balance changes around AD champions is not the death of the mage class.

Why? Because having an all AD team is a bad idea in most cases. Doing all of one kind of damage makes you easy to itemize against. People can focus all their gold into just one of the two resistances and the rest into health and/or damage. And god forbid they build a Thornmail. Or have Rammus.

Or both.

Stop freaking out, people. Please. Just because Riot has been focusing their changes on the other side of the chart doesn't mean that the one not getting as much love is being forgotten entirely. AD champions take up more slots, are usually in more places on a map, and usually act as the engagement or peel for a team so they're picked more often. Not because the mage class is dying, but because the mages have set parameters and uses. They're damage. Damage that mixes up what tanks have to worry about. Some have insane amounts of damage that even stacking like crazy won't save you from, some have a mix of damage and utility to make them horrors in teamfights, some have mobility and damage to make it so that they can juke around whatever you throw at them and then deal their own back. And that's pretty much it. You rarely see a mage initiating a fight. You rarely see them roaming before their lane is won. You don't see them divebombing the enemy team alongside their tank. They have their role, wherever they fall between caster to assassin, and they stick to it. If having a branch of champions focused only on doing one thing to the exclusion of all other possible options were a bad thing, ADCs would have meant the death of the melee champion and, last time I checked, if a Wukong jumps on an ADC he's probably going to get the kill.

Chill out, seriously. Especially when the change being made isn't *even that bad*. I can't tell you how many times I've seen a fed mage build a DFG and just think to myself, "Great, now they've got another free 500+ damage on a hotkey." The play patterns that it creates ARE unfair to play against. They make any amount of MR you build mean next to nothing, which last time I checked quite a lot of people including myself are bringing up more and more often as unhealthy for tanks to deal with, AND does enough damage to rival a champion ability with a button press. In addition, most champions that build it don't even need it to kill you. Aside from the mass AP and the nice chunk of CDR, the effect itself isn't strictly necessary. In a teamfight you shouldn't be focusing the tank in the first place, so you don't need the extra burst on the one person who MIGHT survive your full salvo anyways, and if you're solo against a tank, chances are good that you're still going to kill them long before they can kill you because you're just dealing THAT much damage.

DFG isn't necessary, in fact it's unhealthy. If anything this is one step closer to balancing champions that everyone bitches and moans about like Fizz, Akali, Syndra, Katarina, *insert hyper carry AP champion of choice here*. Funfact: I've built a DFG, in over two years of playing this game, maybe three or four times. Each of which I would realize AFTER getting a kill, or several, that I had never even activated it. Funny how it wasn't necessary for me to perform my job even with the champions who use it. 

I know this may be hard to understand at first, but even the champions who use DFG can still do a lot of damage without it. Something about having a passive 30% boost from another high powered AP item I can think of comes to mind, along with several scaling weapons that AD champions just don't have, and the ability to mix stats together a lot easier than an AD champ can. 

Know how many AD items give MR and CDR on the same thing? 

How about a mass amount of AD along with armor, and an active that makes you invincible for a few seconds?

Oh, and let's not forget about the AD item that multiplies your total AD.

Until the day comes that AP champs are removed from the game, they aren't dying or even on their way to die. There are QQ threads that pop up routinely about how overpowered some of them seem, and people debating over whether or not X AP champion is worth a damn because one person can play them like a master while another whiffs skillshots.

I can almost guarantee that anyone who's complaining about DFG being removed probably lacks vision of the larger picture at play here, and has also complained about an Akali, Fizz, or Leblanc 100-0ing you and it being OP.

Surprise, surprise. This is going to alleviate that issue. Almost like they're balancing the game in response to community outcry about how much assassins are currently dominating the meta. I KNOW, right?? Crazy!

Funny how many people are blind to that. If you think you NEED DFG to be effective, I'd suggest you learn to prioritize and work with your team better instead. I guarantee you that there's nothing it gives you that you couldn't do just fine without.

replies.body:
>Can you not see how casters have been stacking Morello's early and finding out how stupidly overefficient it is for the price? Getting two of them puts you at the CDR cap within the first fifteen to twenty minutes of the game, gives you 300% mana regen, and 160 AP. The only thing that's wasted here is the unique passive. At that point they're free to cast whatever they want whenever they want as often as they want.

At the cost of what?

An early Rabadons?

A Zhonyas that could save their ass?

A rylais for the needed HP+100AP?

Yes, building two morello's is good but you're doing it at the cost or much more effective items just so you won't go OOM. That's how bad mana regen is at this point.

> [{quoted}](name=XMoulinRougeX,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=KkpUmmKE,comment-id=0004,timestamp=2015-01-15T17:39:19.886+0000)
>
> At the cost of what?
> 
> An early Rabadons?
> 
> A Zhonyas that could save their ass?
> 
> A rylais for the needed HP+100AP?
> 
> Yes, building two morello's is good but you're doing it at the cost or much more effective items just so you won't go OOM. That's how bad mana regen is at this point.

I didn't say it was the best choice. But people have been doing it because of how stupidly overefficient the Morellonomicon is. They've been making that choice and BECAUSE it's a bad choice Riot is slapping everyone who's been doing it on the wrist. It works as a gimmick, not as a legitimate build, wildly cost efficient for what it does but coming at the expense of other standard necessary items at the necessary times. This removes, or at least lessens, that issue so that people are building smarter.

> [{quoted}](name=Cale017,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=KkpUmmKE,comment-id=00040000,timestamp=2015-01-15T17:56:14.323+0000)
>
> I didn't say it was the best choice. But people have been doing it because of how stupidly overefficient the Morellonomicon is. They've been making that choice and BECAUSE it's a bad choice Riot is slapping everyone who's been doing it on the wrist. It works as a gimmick, not as a legitimate build, wildly cost efficient for what it does but coming at the expense of other standard necessary items at the necessary times. This removes, or at least lessens, that issue so that people are building smarter.

So now they've made the situation even worse? Do you hear what you're arguing about?

So, before AP laners were forced to buy double morello's because of the mana regen nerf going way too far. Now, Riot has said "NO MORE DOUBLE MORELLOS". So now what? What the hell do we do to offset the mana regen nerf???

The only way to now offset the nerf is to cripple the mid game of a mage with a tear or building a RoA PLUS a mana regen item. Mid game is when they're supposed to be most powerful. 

So now you face this choice. Do you build mana regen items and hope you can scale into late game? Or do you build one mana regen item and hope you don't oom in the middle of a team fight or something else that's crucial? Damned if you do and damned if you don't.

And damned again if you do either because your mid game still sucks and late game, if you're not Cassiopeia, you will still be in the back drop of the emerging ADC with a full build. GG riot!

> [{quoted}](name=XMoulinRougeX,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=KkpUmmKE,comment-id=000400000000,timestamp=2015-01-15T18:30:24.860+0000)
>
> So now they've made the situation even worse? Do you hear what you're arguing about?

Do you realize that making Morello's cost a few hundred more gold doesn't completely ruin the mage class, which is what I'm ACTUALLY arguing about? You're so busy nitpicking that you're missing the big picture. Funny how that was the point of my original post.
> 
> So, before AP laners were forced to buy double morello's because of the mana regen nerf going way too far. Now, Riot has said "NO MORE DOUBLE MORELLOS". So now what? What the hell do we do to offset the mana regen nerf???

Well, for one I'd suggest not spamming spells wantonly. It's a little known fact that pretty much any AP laner can get through the early game without running out of mana if they aren't spamming spells. Almost like you don't NEED mana regen items to preserve your mana. By the time you're at the point where you have to be spamming spells you're going into the midgame, which means that you should have one or two items built already and one of them should be a mana regen item, or a pure mana item, which alleviates the issues you're having with casting spells.

> 
> The only way to now offset the nerf is to cripple the mid game of a mage with a tear or building a RoA PLUS a mana regen item. Mid game is when they're supposed to be most powerful. 

It's interesting. Everyone is bitching and complaining about how hard it is to play AP casters but honestly, I haven't had an issue with it. Maybe because I've always been conservative about my ability use, but that would mean people have to adapt their playstyles and we just can't have that can we?
> 
> So now you face this choice. Do you build mana regen items and hope you can scale into late game? Or do you build one mana regen item and hope you don't oom in the middle of a team fight or something else that's crucial? Damned if you do and damned if you don't.

Most AP midlaners don't hit their stride until the mid to late game ANYWAYS. During the early game, if at all, they're supposed to either be helping teammates get kills or getting help on their own. This isn't making some drastic change to the general power curve, just shifting when they actually hit it. Plus, you can be conservative with your casting early, build a damage item, use it to win your lane and then build the mana regen afterwards, usually on another useful item like Athene's or Morellonomicon, so that you're prepared going into the mid game. Or you can sacrifice some early damage to get early casting power by rushing one of the two and running on your runes and masteries for, *gasp*, a whole ten or fifteen minutes, before building heavy into your damage before teamfights have ever really even started breaking out en masse. In either case by the time the heavy teamfighting starts you've got both damage and regen/bonus mana.

> 
> And damned again if you do either because your mid game still sucks and late game, if you're not Cassiopeia, you will still be in the back drop of the emerging ADC with a full build. GG riot!

If your midgame "still" sucks, then it already sucked and the removal of DFG and the inability to spam abilities isn't going to change that. Late game most AP casters can nuke an ADC without much issue provided they're smart about it and don't just walk up to them trying to do it. I think you're forgetting that during the late game people aren't exactly supposed to be able to fight an ADC one on one. 

The removal of DFG alters how people are abusing the ability to cast spells almost unendingly with extra regen/mana, as with double stacking Morello's and going for the DFG allows you to do. Sitting pretty at a 40% CDR cap with a neverending stream of mana? Well hell, guess you can just spam your abilities all you want and that's considered balanced, right?

Honestly, half the reason Riot has a hard time is people like you, who lack the ability to take a step back and use some foresight to understand why they're making the changes they are and what to expect in the future. I'm a hardcore cynic but most of you people are so obscenely negative against any and everything that Riot does that they could make every champion free to purchase and throw out third tier runes like confetti and people would still complain.

Generally speaking, I do wholesomely agree the removal of the DFG is a necessary evil, it had to go, but I just question and don't necessarily agree this is the right time for it to take its departure from the game.

unless your team of aps cant compete and get enough gold to counter itemize 

mages arent dead 
but everything else is in a better spot 

i played ahri vs bots today (i rly lack time to play real games)
one q here and one q here and i was in base every like 5 minutes because i drained my mana and potions without realy spamming my skills 
i always had them for some time and refiled portions of my mana with dorans ring 

while anything energy based or manaless has the skills of similar potency and cooldowns yet isnt forced to go b like i do  

when mages were 100% of the time at 100% mana energy and manaless champs were ballanced to their level 
now as mages got rekt mana wise energy and manaless champs need neerfs to put them in the spot they should be

You missed the point entirely.

A lot of companies are able to make changes to their items AND balance the characters in their game all in ONE PATCH. They strive to have their game in a state of balance as much as possible.

League of Legends is the only game I've played where they make major changes that they fully admit will break things, then say that they will begin to think of how to fix them at a later patch.

It's probably in part due to their free to play pricing model, which has lead to them having more champions than the game really needs, and more then they can obviously handle. It doesn't make it any less frustrating as a player, either way.

> [{quoted}](name=iainB85,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=KkpUmmKE,comment-id=0006,timestamp=2015-01-15T18:13:05.454+0000)
>
> You missed the point entirely.
> 
> A lot of companies are able to make changes to their items AND balance the characters in their game all in ONE PATCH. They strive to have their game in a state of balance as much as possible.
> 
> League of Legends is the only game I've played where they make major changes that they fully admit will break things, then say that they will begin to think of how to fix them at a later patch.
> 
> It's probably in part due to their free to play pricing model, which has lead to them having more champions than the game really needs, and more then they can obviously handle. It doesn't make it any less frustrating as a player, either way.

Those companies don't also have a game that's being run entirely on the small numbers adding up to big changes the way a League match plays out. When an MMO makes a series of buffs and nerfs it can be that overarching because it isn't an environment where people are going to take any change and run with it to the point that they're abusing the differences. The issue with the League community is that one small change can make a big difference happen over the course of a match.

Like I said, they don't always make the best choices. But they're making the choices they have to for the sake of controlling the path of the buffs and nerfs that they make. You have to experiment with things before you keep making more changes, especially in a game that's basically a model of chaos theory. Not a lot of other companies are running a game like League, in fact I can count the number of MOBAs that are popular on one hand, one of which isn't even fully released yet and another only just hit their full release in the last year.

You actually make the opposite point you think you do with your original post.

You pretty much sum up "mages aren't dead because going all AD makes it too easy to itemize resistances"

IF that is the only reason to go AP, that shows what a poor state it really is in.

> [{quoted}](name=iainB85,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=KkpUmmKE,comment-id=0003,timestamp=2015-01-15T17:37:53.148+0000)
>
> You actually make the opposite point you think you do with your original post.
> 
> You pretty much sum up "mages aren't dead because going all AD makes it too easy to itemize resistances"
> 
> IF that is the only reason to go AP, that shows what a poor state it really is in.

That isn't the only reason to go AP. They also tend to bring more CC or waveclear options than other laners, and in a lot of cases more mobility options as well. That was a point I made to make the easiest possible reason that they're necessary, not the only reason they're necessary. Don't misunderstand.

> [{quoted}](name=Cale017,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=KkpUmmKE,comment-id=00030000,timestamp=2015-01-15T17:57:43.149+0000)
>
> That isn't the only reason to go AP. They also tend to bring more CC or waveclear options than other laners, and in a lot of cases more mobility options as well. That was a point I made to make the easiest possible reason that they're necessary, not the only reason they're necessary. Don't misunderstand.

That is a common misconception -- being an AP champion does not give you more access to wave clear clear, CC, or burst. These exist independently of being AP or AD based.

> [{quoted}](name=iainB85,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=KkpUmmKE,comment-id=000300000000,timestamp=2015-01-15T18:04:30.365+0000)
>
> That is a common misconception -- being an AP champion does not give you more access to wave clear clear, CC, or burst. These exist independently of being AP or AD based.

But are usually more prioritized choices for an AP laner as opposed to a top laner who's more focused on making sure they aren't hard countered or can perform their intended role, or a jungler who's more focused on how they can cut off someone's escape than how they can lock down potentially an entire team with their abilities. Unless you're Amumu. The reason people don't pick them solely for their damage is because it isn't just their damage that wins them matches, it's their ability to use CC to set up for their damage, and as a result they usually have more access to harder CC than you'd find on top laners or junglers in a lot of cases. The only other role that can rival the amount of CC available for AP casters is the support role, and there aren't exactly a whole lot of those, most of whom who have the best CC are, surprise surprise, AP based champions. It isn't strictly limited to the AP casters, no, but it does heavily favor them.

Early in the game, and well into the midgame, you aren't going to find someone with access to as much waveclear as an AP mid has because a single spell from one of them can eat an entire wave in a lot of cases, whereas most ADCs have to take down a wave minion at a time, and top laners have to rely on items like Hydra to eat waves as quickly.
If you read the patch notes the price of Morello's is going up. It's not very efficient any more, which is another blow to AP mana users.

> [{quoted}](name=iainB85,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=KkpUmmKE,comment-id=0005,timestamp=2015-01-15T17:43:50.650+0000)
>
> If you read the patch notes the price of Morello's is going up. It's not very efficient any more, which is another blow to AP mana users.

It's still plenty efficient, it's just not so overefficient that people will want to stack two of them early in the game. Removing DFG will allow them to buff the other items over time as well as the champions who would normally buy a DFG in an environment that keeps DFG from taking any small change made and amplifying it to problematic levels. Without having to worry about a DFG making a champion hit harder than they should be, they can safely put more power into their kits to compensate, and can start slowly tweaking the other items in the midlane now that there isn't a hotkeyed item that takes advantage of them to an extreme.

> [{quoted}](name=Cale017,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=KkpUmmKE,comment-id=00050000,timestamp=2015-01-15T17:54:01.306+0000)
>
> It's still plenty efficient, it's just not so overefficient that people will want to stack two of them early in the game. Removing DFG will allow them to buff the other items over time as well as the champions who would normally buy a DFG in an environment that keeps DFG from taking any small change made and amplifying it to problematic levels. Without having to worry about a DFG making a champion hit harder than they should be, they can safely put more power into their kits to compensate, and can start slowly tweaking the other items in the midlane now that there isn't a hotkeyed item that takes advantage of them to an extreme.

This is what bothers me about Riot's balance style though.

They will remove DFG this patch, gutting a ton of champions so that they are not good choices in competitive play anymore.

This ALLOWS them to START THINKING about MAYBE making some changes to SOME items or SOME champions because that item is gone.

Which means people who enjoyed AP/Mana burst casters will pretty much be SOL for the first half of the season now while Riot figures out WTF they want to do.

They never release a coherent patch where they remove something, and compensate for it at the same time. They just gut things, then go, "We'll figure out how to fix what we broke later."

...it's an awful way up to  update the game IMO and is a major contributor as to why people get so frustrated with Riot frequently.

> [{quoted}](name=iainB85,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=KkpUmmKE,comment-id=000500000000,timestamp=2015-01-15T17:57:25.963+0000)
>
> This is what bothers me about Riot's balance style though.
> 
> They will remove DFG this patch, gutting a ton of champions so that they are not good choices in competitive play anymore.

There's a big difference between gutting a champion and removing something that makes them unhealthy to play against. The fact that so many of these champions rely so heavily on a DFG to do well just shows that the item is doing too much, and that their kits aren't doing enough. But you can't buff their kits without making DFG do so much more from those buffs, so it has to be removed to safely make those changes.

> 
> This ALLOWS them to START THINKING about MAYBE making some changes to SOME items or SOME champions because that item is gone.

This lets them look at who needs more power where in their kits with what effects and at which points in the game. Last time I checked making some changes to some items or some champions is all a set of nerfs or buffs is in the first place. But right now they can't even begin to think about making any buffs to items or champions who normally use a DFG without allowing that DFG buy to ramp up any small change into a big one.

> 
> Which means people who enjoyed AP/Mana burst casters will pretty much be SOL for the first half of the season now while Riot figures out WTF they want to do.

Except that mana users can still win lane. They can still make plays in teamfights, and they can still kill manaless users. Yes, right now they're having a hard time competing with manaless users, who IMO could use some buffs in a few cases. But the reason they're having issues against them isn't the items they have available, and if an item is the only way one of them can hope to keep up, like a DFG seems to be regarded as, it's a sign that the champions need to be strengthened so that they can do well on their own, not having to use an item as a crutch to do it.
> 
> They never release a coherent patch where they remove something, and compensate for it at the same time. They just gut things, then go "We'll figure out how to fix what this broke later."

That's how the process works. If you both remove one thing and strengthen another you get mixed variables when examining the changes that have resulted from it.  Has a champion become dominant because something was removed, or has the other champion become dominant because something was strengthened? League is a game of variables, so these variables have to be examined and changed one at a time. So yes, you have to remove something, see how it effects the state of the game to find out what needs to be changed, and then compensate for it afterwards. They aren't fixing what they broke later, they're making sure they know how to fix something that's already broken so they don't do more damage
> 
> ...it's an awful way up to  update the game IMO and is a major contributor as to why people get so frustrated with Riot frequently.

If people don't want to be patient and lack the ability to look at it all subjectively instead of going into each set of patch notes with a pre-established bias against any and all decisions Riot makes, then they aren't going to be able to contain their unreasonable frustration or even hatred in some extreme cases. Riot is updating the exact same way that any online game updates their in game systems. It's only because League is so amazingly popular, and the community is so stupidly vocal, that it looks like there's an issue with how they run things. I'm not saying they're perfect, but I'm saying the community makes them out to be worse than they actually are when they're really just making the same sorts of decisions that any other online developer has to make, even if they aren't always making the right one. Keep in mind that this is only the fifth year. Most early game companies might be lucky to release a full version of a best selling game in that time, barring the yearly CoD rehash. Honestly Riot deserves some credit for making the game as popular as it is in such a short time, and people need to understand that it isn't easy to keep a game like this running. Not everyone is going to like every change that they make, but they're trying to do what other companies have years of testing to accomplish on a weekly or monthly basis and that is no easy feat.

While yes, you want a varied source of damage so itemization becomes difficult, the biggest problem right now is there is such a massive discrepancy between AD and AP, between manaless user and mana users. This is especially highlighted with manaless AD user as well in the mid lane (Looking at you Zed). Assassins were already rising up to a problematic state, shooting nerfs after nerfs at mages with mana regen doesn't help the situation though, it only escalates it as manaless assassins and fizz are going to sky-rocket in popularity.

The short end of the stick I guess is why worry about being OOM so much when there are other champions who are incredibly potent who don't have that problem? Mana Regen was already posing a huge problem, but now the removal of one of two items which could allow someone to fight back against an assassin is gone, it's just crippling as it is, if this keeps up, the small diversity pool in the mid lane is only going to get smaller. For one example it doesn't take a genius to see that Ahri alone is most likely never going to see a lot of play again.

While I see the point you're trying to make, it's not just about the DFG, its about the state of mana users on the whole that are getting hit hard by this as a collateral. Assassins that use DFG are still going to assassinate their targets without it, in other words, the removal of the DFG does nothing to curb assassins, but only further hurt mages instead.

You talk about itemization, but as it stands right now, considering most AP damage comes from the mid-lane (only exception I can think of is Corki, Ezreal, and Lissandra), why not just play Zed, beat the shit out of the mana user until they are so far behind they literally tickle you.  Which I must say, is disturbingly easy to do so with him, then suddenly, you don't have to worry about AP. If the only reason to use AP simply so you're not using an all AD team, I have to be honest, I think that sums up a huge problem with AP then.

> [{quoted}](name=Droogzy,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=KkpUmmKE,comment-id=0002,timestamp=2015-01-15T17:19:24.067+0000)
>
> While yes, you want a varied source of damage so itemization becomes difficult, the biggest problem right now is there is such a massive discrepancy between AD and AP, between manaless user and mana users. This is especially highlighted with manaless AD user as well in the mid lane (Looking at you Zed). Assassins were already rising up to a problematic state, shooting nerfs after nerfs at mages with mana regen doesn't help the situation though, it only escalates it as manaless assassins and fizz are going to sky-rocket in popularity.

I agree with you, the issue is coming quite a lot from manaless user's overwhelming abilities in lane or during teamfights. But getting a DFG doesn't help an AP mid laner against their opponent, for several reasons. Early on in the game, the mid lane is usually decided by who can get their full salvo out first. Whether or not you have a DFG, if you're smart about how you're setting up for your combo then you're probably going to come out on top. I know this might sound hard to believe, but you can actually win lane against a Zed. The main bulk of the problem with manaless champions is that they can usually stay in lane forever, barring being poked out of it. Buying a DFG neither removes their ability to do this nor significantly increases your chances of killing them any more than any other item, most of which are more useful anyways as a DFG *shouldn't* really be a champion's first buy anyways for every reason that they're removing it. It turns someone who could kill you by being smart about how they do it into someone who can kill you by slamming the hot key and spamming their other abilities wantonly. I agree with you that manaless champions need to be reigned in, but not that DFG is a significant portion of an AP mid's strategy against them, and that losing DFG isn't the death of the mage class as everyone seems to be saying it will be.

> 
> The short end of the stick I guess is why worry about being OOM so much when there are other champions who are incredibly potent who don't have that problem? Mana Regen was already posing a huge problem, but now the removal of one of two items which could allow someone to fight back against an assassin is gone, it's just crippling as it is, if this keeps up, the small diversity pool in the mid lane is only going to get smaller. For one example it doesn't take a genius to see that Ahri alone is most likely never going to see a lot of play again.

Rabadon's allows you to keep up in terms of damage, and Zhonya's allows you to negate a lot of a manaless champ's damage output if you get either of them early. Your options aren't gone, but you're forced to make smarter moves to get that reward than if you were just able to push your DFG key and then a point and click spell or two for the kill. I hate to admit it, but Zed DOES actually take some skill to play. Not necessarily poking with him, but being able to keep up with his movement and set up to get the full use out of your kit when you get your ult, prepositioning your shadows where you hope someone will go once they're ulted, yadda yadda, is no easy feat and you can tell the difference between someone who's spamming his abilities and someone who's set up their kill combo. Getting a DFG removes much of the strategy that a AP caster has to use and just makes being successful with them a matter of how quickly you can spam your abilities while they're debuffed, not how smart they can cast them throughout the game.
> 
> While I see the point you're trying to make, it's not just about the DFG, its about the state of mana users on the whole that are getting hit hard by this as a collateral. Assassins that use DFG are still going to assassinate their targets without it, in other words, the removal of the DFG does nothing to curb assassins, but only further hurt mages instead.

I never said that the mana users weren't falling behind. If you can see my point here then you'd see that the only thing I was pointing out was that the itemization changes don't mean that they're going to fall completely off the charts. The reason they're having an issue is because of the dominance of AD manaless users, as you have already pointed out, and that's got nothing to do with itemization changes on Riot's part. Whether or not DFG is removed, Yasuo will still be able to poke you for free every third Q, Riven will still be able to hit every spell to chunk most of your HP and then do so again ten seconds later. Zed will still be able to get a reduced cooldown on his W and toss a Q at you every few seconds. Riot should be focusing on that, but they have to set up to be able to determine who needs buffs where.
> 
> You talk about itemization, but as it stands right now, considering most AP damage comes from the mid-lane (only exception I can think of is Corki, Ezreal, and Lissandra), why not just play Zed, beat the shit out of the mana user until they are so far behind they literally tickle you.  Which I must say, is disturbingly easy to do so with him, then suddenly, you don't have to worry about AP.

The reason the mage class is struggling right now has nothing to do with the items being changed, it's the competition, and the fact that they're relying on gimmicks to do well against the dominant class at the moment is a sign that there's something inherently wrong. Using a DFG to increase damage output doesn't require any skill, and there's no way to play against it. It's a point and click ability that's on about as long of a cooldown as most AP caster's ults, at least early on, and it reduces a champion with a high skillcap who's heavily reliant on predictive casting or positioning skill to shouting "DFG POWERS ACTIVATE" and bashing their head against their keyboard to fire off everything they have hoping the damage is enough to get them the kill instead of playing smart. That's not a healthy play pattern, and any buffs to champions who use a DFG will very quickly go absolutely out of hand as DFG allows them to do so. But by removing it from the game you can then buff the champions who have come to be known for it in a way that allows them both to compensate for the lost potential damage a DFG gives while forcing them to play smart instead of bashing a sausage against their keys for kills and calling it "outplayed." As it stands, they can't buff champions, or even most of the AP caster items, without DFG taking any change they make and not just running, but flat out sprinting with it as soon as someone builds it.

The long and short of it is, yes, mage champs aren't in the best place right now compared to AD manaless mid laners, or even manaless top laners if they try and go there. But removing DFG is a necessary evil to be able to pinpoint exactly where champions who rely on it would need to be buffed without allowing the champs who use it to run rampant because of it after those buffs. It's the first step to finding their balance.
